div1.head: Newspaper clipping, News, Saturday, January 31, 1903
div1.p:
Maryland Medical Journal Favors
Senator Martin's Bill.

The Maryland Medical Journal for Feb-
ruary comments on the debt of the coun-
try to Major Walter Reed, for whose
widow it is proposed to provide a pension
of $200 a month, a bill to this effect hav-
ing been introduced in the United States
Senate by Senator Martin of Virginia.

Major Reed lost his life through his
yellow-fever investigations in Cuba. The
Medical Journal says:

Dr. Reed was a benefactor of the hu-
man race. His services in the cause of
preventive medicine were beyond all
price. Their pecuniary value to a single
one of the United States for a single
year would pay the proposed pension for
20 years. The saving of an ordinary year
would do this much. If the cost of a
yellow-fever epidemic were considered,
the proposed pension would sink into in-
significance. The cost of yellow fever to
Louisiana in 1878 was $15,000,000 and 4056
lives.

But for the work of Dr. Reed and his
associates at Havana the Isthmian canal
project would yet have been beyond a
reasonable hope of realization. To this
stupendous undertaking the country is
now committed, and it is not improbable
that unless the practical measures which
Gorgas has worked out upon the prin-
ciples stated by Reed, Carroll, Lazear
and Agramoute are put into practice in
the first year of that work. the second
year's work may be postponed indefi-
nitely.
